message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left kidney actually has a shorter renal artery than the right kidney, but a longer renal vein. The left kidney does lie between T12 and L3 and underlies the left 12th rib.

We refer to anatomy resources for help. Option (B) is incorrect because the left renal artery is, in fact, shorter than the right renal artery. The other options are correct: the left kidney has a longer renal vein, it lies between T12 and L3, and underlies the left 12th rib.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein because it runs under the superior mesenteric artery and behind the pancreas, while the right renal vein runs directly into the inferior vena cava. The left kidney does lie between T12 and L3, and it does underlie the left 12th rib. However, the right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery because it runs directly from the aorta to the right kidney, while the left renal artery has to cross the midline of the body to reach the left kidney. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein due to its course passing in front of the aorta, inferior vena cava, and vertebral column.
